Eugene Kuleshov wrote:
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>  >>  > On 28/11/05, David Jackman <david.jackman@...> wrote:
>  >>  > >  In this case, I would have my test ping each URL, then in case of
>  >>  > >  failure add the URL to a list of failed URLs (no assertions 
> here).  At
>  >>  > >  the end of the loop, assert that the list of failed URLs is 
> empty and
>  >>  > >  have the failure message include the list of URLs.
>  >>  >
>  >>  > Or google for parameterized test case, which has been discussed on
>  >>  > this list fairly recently with good examples.
>  >>
>  >> Yes, it's the standard design pattern for this.
>  >>
>  >> But why wouldn't I be able to pass parameters to my test methods, 
> just like
>  >> I do all the time in "regular" Java?
>  >>    
>  > That's the price we pay for being able to collect tests automatically
>  > through reflection.
>  >  
>   Hmm. Why would it be a problem to pass params using reflection?

I suppose it would be possible to discover test methods with parameters, 
then search for parameter sources. I wonder what that would look like...

>   I think that the right answer is that there are no test method, but
> test cases that should be executed in isolation and because of that you
> can't call them directly, so JUnit is using Command pattern for that and
> in such design params are passed upon command creation.

That's certainly the case, but it doesn't mean we can't do it... it just 
might be really weird. I'm not up to trying it. :)
